metadata.title: How a team of deep learning newbies came 3rd place in a kaggle contest | by Mercy Markus | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How a team of deep learning newbies came 3rd place in a kaggle contest
metadata.description: The Women in Data Science in collaboration with their partners initiated the WiDS datathon. The challenge was to create a model that predicts the presence of oil palm plantations in satellite…

all_paragraphs: The Women in Data Science in collaboration with their partners initiated the WiDS datathon. The challenge was to create a model that predicts the presence of oil palm plantations in satellite imagery. Planet and Figure Eight generously provided an annotated dataset of satellite images recently taken by Planet’s satellites. The dataset images are of 3-meter spatial resolution, and each is labeled based on the presence of an oil palm plantation in the image (0 for no plantation, 1 for the presence of a plantation). The task was to train a model that takes as input a satellite image and outputs a prediction of the likelihood of an image containing an oil palm plantation. Labeled training and test datasets were provided for model development by the competition creators. Read more here.

My Teammates and I (Abdishakur, Halimah, and Ifeoma Okoh) used the fast.ai framework for this challenge. Big thanks to Thomas Capelle🤗 for his starter kernel on kaggle, it provided so much insight into how to approach this problem and also the fast.ai team for creating an amazing deep learning course that simplifies a lot of difficult deep learning concepts. Now beginners to deep learning can now go as far as winning kaggle contests 😁.

Don’t worry about understanding everything just yet, that’ll come with lots of practice. This tutorial is meant to show you how cool fast.ai is for beginners to deep learning. I’m assuming you know some python and you’ve dabbled with ML a little. If that’s you; then we are on track.

All the code shown here is available on Google Colaboratory; a free Jupyter notebook environment that requires no setup and runs entirely in the cloud. With Colaboratory you can write and execute code, save and share your analyses, and access powerful computing resources, all for free from your browser. Click here to access the code we’ll be using.

To keep this as straight forward as possible, Abdishakur uploaded the competition datafiles to dropbox.com. You can find them on the competition webpage here. You’ll need to accept the rules of the competition and join to have access to the data.

The first thing to do when we approach a problem is to take a look at the available data. We’ll need to understand the problem and what the data looks like before we can figure out how to solve it. Taking a look at the data means understanding how the data directories are structured, what the labels are and what some sample images look like.

The main difference between handling image classification datasets and tabular datasets is the way labels are stored. Labels here refers to what’s in the image. In this particular dataset, labels were stored in a CSV file.
To find out more about how the score column was calculated, click here.

We’ll use seaborn’s countplot function to look at the distribution of our training data. From the plot, we can see that about 14,300 of the images do not have oil palm plantations present in them while only 942 of the images have. This is known as an unbalanced dataset and it’s a deep learning problem we are not going to cover here; we are taking baby steps at the moment 👶🏽.

The test data provided are in two separate folders, the leaderboard holdout data, and leaderboard test data. We are going to combine both cause it’s a competition requirement to submit predictions for both sets. We have 6534 images combined.
We’ll be using fast.ai’s DataBlock API to structure the data, it’s a hassle-free way of presenting our datasets to our models.
Here’s how satellite images with or without oil palm plantations look like:

Now we train our model. We’ll use a convolutional neural network backbone and use pre-trained weights from a resnet model that has been trained to classify a wide range of images. Don’t worry about what this means in detail. For now, we are building a model which takes satellite images as input and outputs the predicted probability for the two categories.
Next, we find an ideal learning rate using lr_find() and visualize this using recorder.plot().
We’ll select a learning rate close to where our slope is steepest,1e-2 in our case.
We’ll train our model for 5 epochs (5 cycles through all our data) using the fit_one_cycle function.
Notice the metrics getting displayed i.e training_loss and valid_loss? We use them to monitor model improvements over time.
Our best model was obtained at the 4th epoch.
fast.ai internally picks and saves only your best models when you run through your training and validation datasets.

The competition submissions were evaluated based on the Area under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve between the predicted probability and the observed target, has_oilpalm. Learn more about AUC in this developer crash course, this video, or this Kaggle Learn Forum post. Fast.ai doesn’t come with this metric by default, so we’ll be using the scikit-learn library.
The beauty of using pre-trained models and fast.ai is that you get a really good prediction accuracy, 99.44% in our case without doing the most.
Let’s save our model and plot a confusion matrix about the predictions made.
A confusion matrix is a graphical way of seeing the number of images your model accurately or inaccurately predicts.

From this plot, we can see that the model accurately predicts 2,863 images as not having oil palm plantations in them, 168 images with oil palm plantations were correctly classified. 10 images that contained oil palm plantation were classified as not having any and then 7images without oil palm plantations were classified as having them.
Not bad for a simple model 🥳.
Next, we find an ideal learning rate for this training iteration.
Fit the model using a maximum learning rate that is between1e-6 and 1e-4 for 7 epochs.
Observe the training metrics graphically to monitor the model’s performance after each training cycle.
Save the second stage of model training.
Print out the model’s accuracy, error rate and Area Under the Curve metrics.
Upon comparison with the last confusion matrix we plotted, you’ll notice that the model makes better predictions.
Formerly 7 images that didn't have oil palm plantations were misclassified, now we are down to 3. That’s progress.

You’ll notice we’ve been following a pattern during training and tweaking a few parameters in the course of this. What we’ve been doing is called tuning. Most deep learning experiments follow a similar iterative pattern.
We’ll perform some more image transformations on our data. This should improve our model. A detailed description of what each transform does can be found in the fast.ai documentation:
We find an optimal learning rate again.
Compare the training metrics and compare with past metrics. Our model is slightly worse on this iteration 0.0169 versus 0.0163 . Don’t despair just yet.

Save the third stage of model training and print out the metrics. As you’ll notice the model’s accuracy is now 99.38% , it was99.48% in the previous stage. The AUC score improved from 99.87% to 99.91%, this is the metric the competition is graded on.

If you notice we started with the images having size = 164 and we gradually built up till we arrived at size = 256 down below. We did this to take advantage of fast.ai’s progressive image resizing for classification i.e using small images at the start of training, and gradually increasing size as training progresses. That way, when the model is very inaccurate early on, it can quickly see lots of images and make rapid progress, and later in training, it can see larger images to learn about more fine-grained distinctions. To read more about this click here.
We find an optimal learning rate again.
Fit the model using a learning rate of 1e-4 for 5 epochs.
Observe the training metrics and compare with past metrics. Our model is made a slight improvement, from 0.0169 to 0.0168.
Save the final stage of model training and print out the metrics.
As you’ll notice the model’s accuracy is now 99.44% which is an improvement from the last training stage which was99.38%.
Now we can see how well our model makes predictions on data it’s yet to see.

You can still enter the WiDS competition and make a late submission. To do that go to the competition page here, click on Join Competition and accept the competition’s rules. Now you can make a submission to see where you would have ranked if you participated.
Disclaimer: The instructions in the article won’t place you in 3rd position as we did, I wanted to keep this as simple as possible. To figure that out, check out Abdishakur’s post about it here.
Curious to learn more? Check out this amazing 7 Part lecture series curated by Jeremy Howard and the fast.ai team.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Excited about learning new things. I’m currently learning about the cloud by building and maintaining scalable systems on it.
